Award.AbstractNarration:
Representation theory seeks to classify and describe the possible realizations of symmetries, and to exploit symmetry by providing a tool to decompose symmetric structures into elementary constituents. Representation theory has been an essential tool in quantum physics almost from its inception, providing for example the structure of atomic orbitals. Gauge theories, quantum theories built directly out of the structure of local symmetry, are the language of much of high energy physics, in particular the Standard Model, which describes all the fundamental forces besides gravity. Gauge theory in turn has had a tremendous impact on low dimensional topology and geometry. This project is concerned with the reversal of the relationship between representation theory and gauge theory: applying the structure of gauge theory as a powerful organizing framework for representation theory in the abstract. In this paradigm, different representation theories are encoded by different models of gauge theory, and inherit a radically new and uniform structure from the behavior of observables and defects in gauge theory. Thus the fundamental symmetries of nature become powerful tools to understand the most abstract questions in algebra and analysis -- in particular some of the deepest structures we know in algebra (the Langlands program, responsible for the resolution of Fermat's Last Theorem) derive from the symmetry between electricity and magnetism. These connections and synergies will be developed under this project, both in the PI's research and in his extensive expository work, including writing a graduate text introducing this paradigm to a broader audience for the first time.

Gauge theories are quantum field theories built directly out of local Lie group symmetry. Conversely, one can view many aspects of representation theory of Lie groups through the lens of gauge theory, which provides a powerful organizing principle for representation theory through the medium of low-dimensional topology. The object of this project is to develop and disseminate the perspective of representation theory as gauge theory. The project details two primary research projects inspired by developments in gauge theory. The first is the exploitation of a new source of commutative symmetry algebras in geometric representation theory inspired by Seiberg-Witten geometry of gauge theory and uncovered in the PI's recent work. The PI will apply spectral decomposition with respect to these symmetries in a variety of contexts, including Lusztig's theory of character sheaves, the homology of character varieties of surfaces, and the geometric Langlands correspondence. The second is the development of the new "Betti" (or topological) form of the Geometric Langlands Correspondence introduced by the PI, which he intends to reduce to elementary building blocks by proving an "automorphic Verlinde formula." The case of genus one appears accessible, and has implications for much-studied topics in representation theory. In addition the PI intends to engage in extensive expository writing, including a graduate text and interdisciplinary expository work with theoretical high energy physicists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant "Representation Theory as Gauge Theory" was focused on developing new connections between algebra and number theory, on the one hand, and mathematical physics, on the other hand. I developed the perspective that the algebraic study of symmetry and its manifestations (representation theory) can be greatly enhanced by embedding it in the remarkably rich and powerful framework of quantum field theory, specifically supersymmetric gauge theory -- the physics of ``internal symmetries" in its most structured form. 

The Broader Impact outcomes of this project came from the dissemination of this powerful perspective through numerous expository lectures and lecture series, on the one hand, and through training undergraduate and graduate students in this perspective, on the other (including the supervision of seven doctoral students through the grant period). The impact was enhanced by my frequent discussions with a broad range of both mathematicians and physicists, from the junior to the most senior and established levels, bridging the gaps between the groups and sharing a unifying point of view. 

The project resulted in several significant outcomes for the Intellectual Merit criterion. I collaborated with a group of physicists (Beem, Bullimore, Dimofte and Neitzke) on a paper in which we found new "higher symmetry" structures in supersymmetric field theory by applying insights from algebra and topology, developing a new line of communication between the fields. I concluded a series of papers with Gunningham with the discovery of a new symmetry principle in representation theory inspired directly by field theory ideas -- a universal way to integrate flows of a large family of quantum Hamiltonian systems. With Ganev I applied geometry to provide a simple conceptual explanation for subtle analytic results of Harish-Chandra on the asymptotic behavior of special functions. Moreover I concluded the majority of a collaboration with Chen, Helm and Nadler in which we used geometric ideas, again inspired by field theory, to support an emerging new and stronger version of the local Langlands correspondence, the central structure in the representation theory of p-adic groups.

The most exciting outcome of the project was the start of an ambitious long-term collaboration with Sakellaridis and Venkatesh in which the principle "Representation theory as gauge theory" provided new insights into number theory, and one of the few known direct connections of that venerated subject with quantum field theory. The so-called Relative Langlands Program seeks to organize the zoo of examples in which L-functions (one of the main objects of study in number theory) have representatios as integrals -- also known as periods of automorphic forms. We found that the perspective of gauge theory gives a completely new and conceptual way to organize this subject -- the key idea is that both period integrals and L-functions can be viewed as boundary conditions in (an arithmetic analog of) 4d gauge theory, and the relation between the two is achieved by electric-magnetic duality. This project is being widely disseminated and is having a significant impact on the subject, and expect I will continue to be the focus of my research for a long time.
